												Before we begin let me just say that there's a chicken and the egg paradox here: Nobody wants to buy this game because it's dead, but it's only dead because nobody wants to buy this game. So for those of you who just want to know how active the game is right now, the answer is "dead as dead can be". At the time of this review I have successfully completed 14 matches after having "played" for 36 hours.If this was a free game then maybe the user population wouldn't such a problem that it is now, but it's not. This game will usually get a 75% discount during major Steam sales, if you see it, buy it. And here's why.Picture League of Legends in space, that's the gist of this game. But there's much more to it that than. There's an overall ship progression that carries over from games that allows your ship to grow more powerful over a period of time. At the end of each match you'll usually get rewarded with augments, weapons, and medals to customize your ship. And you can choose between 4 different skills to take into battle to better fit your playstyle, and as these type of games go you also have an "ultimate ability" late game to make that final push towards the enemy HQ easier.There are two main game modes: Conquest and Battlefield. Conquest is the main League mode where each team tries to sweep across the map and smash the opposing HQ. What's really great however is that there's an emphasis on teamwork because there's a shared technology/upgrade pool. You can spend your credits to upgrade yourself OR you can give it to the team and upgrade your faction's capabilities, particularly the strength of your minion ships. Plenty of potential for strong team coordination.There are a total of 6 ships available by defualt and 4 DLC ships with unique mechanics you can purchase that greatly change the playing field. If you're going to get this game might as well opt in for the full bundle and get those 4 ships, at it's 75% discount they'll literally only cost pennies.A quick breatdown of the DLC ships:Science Vessal - First of all this is the only ship to begin at level 2. It has some powerful board manipulating skills including scrambling the enemy's movement and a tractor beam to drag your victims into your team's firing range. It's ultimate is an all consuming blackhole.Support Ship - The ability to drop turrets and repair station on the field is a powerful advantage, the support ship lives up to it's name by being a power tactical asset to your team.The Carrier - Introduces a new squadron mechanic to the game. You are able to launch fighters that allow you to "hit & run" from a distance and harass the enemy frontlines.Artillary Ship - Is able to bombard from a distance. Instead of line-or-sight like most ships the special cannon does almost instant damage with it's barrages. Fully upgrading your range will allow you to sit comfortably behind your allies while chipping away at the enemies defences with little worry for your personal safety.Is the game dead? Unfortunately yes. Should you buy it at full price? Probably not. Should you buy it when it's on sale? Hell yes! Should you tell your friends to buy it? Definitely yes!!For those of you who do end up giving this game a try a few quick tips: The majority of the remaining player base is European, so if you want to find a good game chances are you'll need to adjust to their timezone. If you can't find a game you can at least do a PRACTICE MATCH against the computer. (A lot of people complain that they haven't been able to try out all the ships without realizing there's a practice option.) You won't get any experience towards leveling your ship, and you won't get to have any real ship on ship battles, the maps only have minions and turrets. But it's a way to get familiar with your ship without the pressure trying to win.This is a really great game whose only real problem is a lack of players.

												Let me indulge into why I say Yes to this game.  One, the game's graphics are well done in specs for how much you can purchase it for.  There are very few glitches overall in the game which makes playability enjoyable.Although, the lack of advertisement and support was this games down-fall.  It truly is a sad deal when a great game falls short.  Only for the fact of lost vision.Currently you will find that the game has almost no one playing.  The ones that are playing are usually a group of four to eight people or more... that know each other and have the game.  Sadly, you'll be hard pressed to get people to game with.  There use to be a public TeamSpeak server for the game.  It was a form of assistance to help find games and teammates, as well as communication for in game.This game could easily make a come-back if the creators and or current holders probably changed a few things... what I feel they could change to improve it.1- Change how DLC works, for example new ships costing money is not a bad idea for a space battling game.  It is very much like League of Legends, Dota, or many others in this field of play.  Change it, but how?  You ask...  Well simple, currently many have bought the game so you might as well just let them have the DLC and Ships currently available.While allowing new users to unlock these ships after meeting certain criteria.1.5- Coming off the first improvement would be including a ranking system.  Example would be using Air-force or other forms of ranking to enlist Player's rank in games.  Someone who has played enough games to be seen as a veteran or a pro could be listed as a General.  Using XP and Wins to show their personal abilities.  You could even make it rank specific to ships.... meaning I could be a Commander Specialist on a Dreadnaught but a Rookie on a Destroyer.  Granted these ships already have a leveling system which enables survivability, but not game-breaking..2- Servers, servers, server!  Find a deal or a means to get cheap and affordable server(s) that are not atrocious!  Heck, the current game building is not bad actually!  Although servers would allow them to create updates, new events, things that many games are now adopting.3- Advertisement!  I honestly never even seen any advertisement effort.  If there was it was not enough.  DOTA and LoL did not get to where they are just by fan-base alone.  They sold themselves like an individual who willing sells them self for $2.00 an hour!  I mean seriously... Not enough advertisment!  When can you have too much advertisement?  When you have people laughing at the advertisment because they see it as silly... when it becomes SO normal that when it's missing they go... oh, hey... that's a new billboard?3.5- Youtube, Google, Steam, Facebook, MySpace, and soo much more!  Heck, Youtube and Facebook you don't even need to pay for!  Be shameless in your advertisement, go all out if need be.  Blow the game up to superb expectations just to fall flat but then raise the game to those expectations once the money rolls!  Simple, no?and my conclusion...  I just followed what a bunch of others have probably said about this game... those hard-core gaming members out there that enjoy a space battle.  This game is good for a top-down battle game in space.  It gives you that feeling at least... just depressing the game has essentially disappeared due to the current holders and or creators just giving up on it.  Sad days for such hard work that they put into a potentially fine game.I rest my rant.

												Stellar Impact is a strategic real time space combat game that gets a lot of things right.  The graphics and sound are well done and the control scheme is simple enough to learn quickly. 												I can't recommend this game. Do not pick it up. It is conceptionally flawed in a way that prevents any newbie to win against a veteran player. I bought this game during a sale, because its concept was nice. Back then, it was a few months after release, the game was almost dead already. (It is dead right now)The game was fun for the first couple matches, because there were a good amount of newbies and 2nd Tier ships at most around. At that point the game was balanced. After a few more matches a Vetern joined with a Tier 5 ship. In a 5v5 match setup our complete team, all newbies in Tier 1 and Tier 2 ships, kept firing at that guys ship and he won. He literally outtanked all of our damage and killed us 1v5. It wasn't that we were bad, it was just that our ships weren't leveled enough. Not enough damage, not enough hull. The Tiers are balanced to each other but as newbie in this game you have lost the match before it even started.It is the reason this game is dead. No one will put up the required hours to die their way to a max level Ship, just to be on equal footing with people that played the game much longer. I soon there after abandoned the match, as the realisation sunk in with the end of the promo weekend, that there just weren't enough newbies around anymore to have fun or level up.The game's mechanics canabilse its own newbies, by making it completely impossible for them to have fun if they are in a match with people that played the game for much longer.It was a good and interesting game, as long everything was balanced, but the low player base means you'll be joining matches with veterns in much stronger ships than your little dingy ship can measure up to. Its a fun game to play during sales, when new blood gets into the game, but as soon as the sale dies down, you are most likely going to deinstall the game.Save your money.
